Award.AwardTitle: SBIR (RAPID):Process Development to Restore Osorb Swelling Glass Fouled While Recovering Gulf Oil-Water Mixtures
Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID proposal will perform urgent research and development to adapt the use of Osorb, an organophilic swellable glass, for remediation of crude oil contamination in the Guld of Mexico. The proposer is already developing advanced water purification systems designed around the unique properties of the nano-engineered Osorb material. Prior to the Deepwater Horizon accident, we were actively working on systems to use Osorb to purify water produced in oil extraction and recovery with partnering oil and gas companies. The waters to be treated included produced water and frac fluids. We are now being tasked commercially to re-engineer our systems to handle ocean water contaminated with crude oil from the gulf. Preliminary testing has identified a key series of challenges that need to be addressed on our research and development side which center about developing methods to rapidly restore the Osorb in modified produced water treatments systems to handle heavy weathered petroleum inputs. The strategy to solve the regeneration problem will start at the bench level and has the potential to rapidly progress to full scale engineering designs, based on leveraging the NSF funding. The intent is to complete the project in 45 days.

The broader impact of this work will be to provide a new process and material system for remediation of crude oil contamination in the Gulf of Mexico and elsewhere. The Osorb material has the potential to solve a key challenge in the clean-up process (removal and disposal of certain emulsions) and therefore to greatly enhance and accelerate the clean-up effort. It also has the potential for large societal and economic benefits beyond the current crisis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
ABSMaterials, Inc. received a RAPID award for testing and engineering its produced water purification system for treatment of Gulf of Mexico waters affected by the Deepwater Horizon incident. The technology is based on Osorb, the trademarked commercial name for swellable organically modified silica which can absorb to up 8X its own weight in organic liquids such as petroleum.  Osorb is like a sponge for dissolved hydrocarbons.  As it swells, it can lift 20,000 times its own weight.  The primary objectives of the research were the following:

  1. Measure the capture rate of high viscous oils by Osorb.
  2. Develop a rapid mechanism to rinse Osorb of the captured heavy oil.
  3. Develop system where recovered oil can be delivered back as product.

We began work the same day we received notification of funding.  This included final paperwork for deployment with US Coast Guard who was coordinating clean-up efforts to allow operation. Concurrently, we began bench-scale and pilot research to address project goals. As our project ramped up, the organizations involved in managing the spill pursued the strategy of injecting dispersants (chemical surfactants) directly into the fluids as the left the broken piping on the sea floor.

Use of dispersants released the oil as a colloidal dispersion into the deep ocean as a means to prevent impact of coastal wetlands by free-floating petroleum. As this situation unfolded, we began work with a contractor hired to treat water-oil mixtures collected near the surface. In particular, ABS Materials focused on removing the dissolved oil, dispersed/emulsified oil, and chemical surfactants used as dispersants.  It was found that our trailer-mounted unit (60 gallons/minute) could remove 99% of the oil and 50—60% of the chemical surfactants. Larger scale systems are being designed in part as a result of this work.

ABSMaterials’ technology developed in part under this RAPID grant will be used on a day-to-day basis to prevent environmental impact of oil extraction activities.  In this manner, the technology has been brought to market at a faster pace by our attention to the disaster.
